lesson.name: Lesson 1.3: Writing Equations to Model Relationships, Part 2

page.title: 1.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to develop your ability to identify, describe, and model relationships with mathematics.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use words and equations to describe the patterns in a table of values or in a set of calculations.
  • Use representations, like diagrams and tables, to help make sense of a described situation and write equations for it.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 3.1: Finding a Relationship between x and y
  • 1.3.2: Describing Relationships Using Words and Equations
  • 1.3.2: Self Check
  • 1.3.3: Identifying and Representing Relationships
  • 1.3.3: Self Check
  • 1.3.4: Writing an Equation to Represent a Relationship>

After that, you‚Äôll practice and review.

  • 1.3.5: Practice
  • 1.3.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.3.1: Finding a Relationship between ùíô and ùíö
page.contents:
Warm-Up Activity


Here is a table of values. The two quantities, \( x \) and \(y \), are related.

\( x \) \( y \)
\(1\) \(0\)
\(3\) \(8\)
\(5\) \(24\)
\(7\) \(48\)

What are some strategies you could use to find a relationship between \( x \) and \(y \)? Brainstorm as many ways as possible.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to the following sample responses:

  • See if there is an operation that could be done to \( x \) that would produce \( y \).
  • Compare how the \( x \)-values change and the \( y \)-values change, and see if there is a pattern.
  • See if the numbers in one column follow a special pattern and if that pattern could be connected to the numbers in the other column.
  • Plot the \( x \)- and \( y \)-values on a coordinate plane and see if the graph looks like a familiar relationship.

page.title: 1.3.2: Describing Relationships Using Words and Equations
page.contents:
Activity

1. Create a math story that describes how the two quantities in each table are related.

Table A

number of laps, \(x \)

0

1

2.5

6

9

meters run, \(y \)

0

400

1,000

2,400

3,600

 

Table B

meters from home, \(x \)

0

75

128

319

396

meters from school, \(y \)

400

325

272

81

4

 

Table C

electricity bills in dollars, \(x \)

85

124

309

816

total expenses in dollars, \(y \)

485

524

709

1,216

 

Table D

Monthly salary in dollars, \(x \)

872

998

1,015

2,110

Amount deposited in dollars, \(y \)

472

598

615

1,710


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to these sample responses:

  • Table A: Every lap is 400 meters, so the distance run is 400 times the number of laps.
  • Table B: The distance between home and school is 400 meters. Every meter traveled away from home is a meter closer to school.
  • Table C: Total expenses can be found by adding $400 to electricity bills. (The $400 could represent rent payment.)
  • Table D: The amount deposited is $400 less than the monthly salary. (The employer might deduct $400 per paycheck for taxes, health insurance, retirement savings, and so on. Or, the employee might first pay $400 in rent or other expenses before depositing the rest of the monthly salary.)

2. Now, match each table of the tables above to an equation that represents the relationship.

  • Equation 1: \( 400 + ùë• = ùë¶ \)
  • Equation 2: \( ùë• - 400 = ùë¶ \)
  • Equation 3: \( ùë• + ùë¶ = 400 \)
  • Equation 4: \( 400‚ãÖùë• = ùë¶ \)

INSERT MATCHING INTERACTIVE

Table A: Equation 4
Table B: Equation 3
Table C: Equation 1
Table D: Equation 2

END MATCHING INTERACTIVE

Video: Describing Relationships 

Watch the following video to learn more about describing relationships using words and equations, specifically looking at the base and height of different rectangles.

  

Extending Your Thinking 

Express every number between 1 and 20 at least one way using exactly four 4s and any operations. For example, 1 could be written as \( \frac{4}{4}+4-4 \).

Write your answer here:

Sample response:

\(1= \frac{4}{4}+4-4 \)

\(2= \frac{4}{4}+\frac{4}{4} \)

\(3= \sqrt4+\sqrt4-\frac{4}{4} \)

\(4= \sqrt4+\sqrt4+4-4 \)

\(5= \sqrt4+\sqrt4+\frac{4}{4} \)

\(6= 4+\frac{4+4}{4} \)

\(7= 4+4-\frac{4}{4} \)

\(8= \sqrt4+\sqrt4+\sqrt4+\sqrt4 \)

\(9= 4+4+\frac{4}{4} \)

\(10= (4+\frac{4}{4})\sqrt4 \)

\(11= \frac{4!\sqrt4-4}{4} \)

\(12= 4(4-\frac{4}{4}) \)

\(13= \frac{4!\sqrt4+4}{4} \)

\(14= 4\cdot4-\frac{4}{\sqrt4} \)

\(15= 4\cdot4-\frac{4}{4} \)

\(16= 4+4+4+4 \)

\(17= 4\cdot4+\frac{4}{4} \)

\(18= 4\cdot4+4-\sqrt4 \)   
   
\(19= 4!-(4+\frac{4}{4}) \)

\(20= 4(4+\frac{4}{4}) \)

page.title: 1.3.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Miles from Home, \( x \)

0

5

10

Miles from School, \( y \)

30

25

20


Using the table above, what is an equation that shows the relationship between miles from home and miles from school?

answer.response: Incorrect. This equation works for the first column, but not the others. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Look for a pattern that works for every column. How do the \( y \)-values change as the \( x \)-values change? The answer is \( y=30-x \).

Incorrect. This equation works for the third column, but not the others. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Look for a pattern that works for every column. How do the \( y \)-values change as the \( x \)-values change? The answer is \( y=30-x \).
That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: The student lives 30 miles from school, so subtract how far they are from home to see how far they are from school at any given time.

Incorrect. This equation does not work for any value of \( x \). Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Look for a pattern that works for every column. How do the \( y \)-values change as the \( x \)-values change? The answer is \( y=30-x \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.3.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Number of guests, \( g \)

1

2

3

12

Number of cupcakes per guest, \( n \)

24

12

8

2

What is one way to write the relationship between the number of guests and the number of cupcakes per guest from the table above?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: Each guest does not get 24 cupcakes. The total number will always be 24 cupcakes. The correct answer is \( n=\frac{24}{g} \).
That‚Äôs correct! Check yourself: The 24 cupcakes will be divided by the number of guests, so this is the correct answer.
Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: The number of cupcakes for each guest is found by dividing the total cupcakes by the number of guests. The correct answer is \( n=\frac{24}{g} \).

Incorrect. Let‚Äôs try again a different way: This does not work for the values in the table. The number of cupcakes for each guest is found by dividing the total cupcakes by the number of guests. The correct answer is \( n=\frac{24}{g} \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.3.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1 and 2, use this scenario: Two different telephone carriers offer the following plans that a person is considering. Company A has a monthly fee of $20 and charges of $.05/min for calls. Company B has a monthly fee of $5 and charges $.10/min for calls.

1. Find the model for the entire  cost, c,  when Company A‚Äôs plan is used for m minutes.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.3.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is c=20 + 0.05m. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Find the model for the entire cost, c, when  Company B‚Äôs plan is used for m minutes.

Correct!

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.3.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is b. c= 5 + 0.10m. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. If a carpenter sawed a 10-ft board into two sections and one section was n ft long, how long would the other section, S, be in terms of n ?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.3.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is S=10-n. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the table below for problems 4 and 5:
Tyler needs to complete this table for his consumer science class. He knows that 1 tablespoon contains 3 teaspoons and that 1 cup contains 16 tablespoons.

number of
teaspoons		 number of
tablespoons

number of
cups

  1. _____
  1. _____

2

36

12
  1. _____
  1. _____

48

3

4. For each of the missing spaces in the table above, a-d, select the missing value that helps complete the table.

a.________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 96. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b.________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 32. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

c.________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac34\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

d.________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 144. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. Choose the equation that represents the number of teaspoons, t, contained in a cup, C.

Correct!

Try again: Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.3.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (c=\frac t{48}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. The volume of dry goods, like apples or peaches, can be measured using bushels, pecks, and quarts. A bushel contains 4 pecks, and a peck contains 8 quarts.
What is the relationship between the number of bushels, b, and the number of quarts, q?

Correct!

Try again. Why don‚Äôt you go back to activity 1.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(b=\frac q{32}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.3.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use words and equations to describe the patterns in a table of values or in a set of calculations.
  • Use representations, like diagrams and tables, to help make sense of a described situation and write equations for it.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.3.1: Finding a Relationship between \( x \) and \( y \)
    • In this activity, you brainstormed ways to find the relationship between variables in a table.
  • 1.3.2: Describing Relationships Using Words and Equations
    • In this activity, you matched tables with the equations that could model the relationships in each table.
  • 1.3.2: Self Check 
  • 1.3.3: Identifying and Representing Relationships
    • In this activity, you created tables from a situation and then wrote an equation to model the relationship.
  • 1.3.3: Self Check 
  • 1.3.4: Writing an Equation to Represent a Relationship
    • In this activity, you wrote an equation to model a relationship in a situation and also began to solve an equation given one of the quantities in the equation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.3.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you‚Äôve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 1.3.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Modeling Linear Equations

Given a real-world problem, model a linear equation to fit it using these steps:

Step 1 Identify known quantities.
Step 2 Assign a variable to represent the unknown quantity.
Step 3 If there is more than one unknown quantity, find a way to write the second unknown in terms of the first.
Step 4 If helpful, create a table of values to see the pattern.
Step 5 Write an equation interpreting the words as mathematical operations.

Let‚Äôs look at an example. Using the steps above, we can model a linear equation to solve a real-world application.

Cell phone Company A charges a monthly service fee of $34 plus $0.05/min talk-time. 

Step 1: Identify the known quantities.
Company A: Monthly Fee: $34, Cost per Minute: $0.05

Step 2: Assign a variable to represent the unknown quantity.
\( t \): total cost (in dollars)
\( m \): number of minutes

Step 3: If there is more than one unknown quantity, find a way to write the second unknown in terms of the first.

Step 4: If helpful, create a table of values to see the pattern.


Company A:

Minutes talked in one month

0

1

2

3

100

Total for one month (dollars)

34

34.05

34.10

34.15

39

Step 5: Write an equation interpreting the words as mathematical operations.
Company A: The total cost, \( t \), equals the fee, 34, plus 0.05 per minute, \( 0.05m \).

 \( t = 34 + 0.05m \)


Try It: Modeling Linear Equations

Cell phone Company B charges a monthly service fee of $40 plus $0.04/min talk-time. Write an equation to describe the relationship between the number of minutes and the total cost.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.


Here is how to find an equation that represents the situation:

Identify known quantities.

Monthly Fee: $40, Cost per Minute: $0.04

Assign a variable to represent the unknown quantity.

\( t \): total cost (in dollars)

\( m \): number of minutes

If there is more than one unknown quantity, find a way to write the second unknown in terms of the first.

  

If helpful, create a table of values to see the pattern.

Company B:

Minutes talked in one month

0

1

2

3

100

Total for one month (dollars)

40

40.04

40.08

40.12

44

Write an equation interpreting the words as mathematical operations.

The total cost, \( t \), equals the fee, 40, plus 0.04 per minute, \( 0.04m \).

 \( t = 40 + 0.04m \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.3.3: Identifying and Representing Relationships
page.contents:
Activity

1. The table represents the relationship between the base length and the height of some parallelograms. Both measurements are in inches.

base length
(inches)

height
(inches)
1 48
2 24
3 16
4 12
6 8

What is the relationship between the base length and the height of these parallelograms?

Write your answer here:

Sample responses:

  • As the base length increases by 1, the height decreases, but not by a steady amount.
  • Multiplying the base length and the height gives 48. The area of each parallelogram is 48 square inches.
  • \( b\cdot h=48 \), or \(\frac{48}{b}=h \) (or equivalent).
  • The height varies inversely as \( b \).


2. Visitors to a carnival are invited to guess the number of beans in a jar. The person who guesses the correct number wins $300. If multiple people guess correctly, the prize will be divided evenly among them.

What is the relationship between the number of people who guess correctly and the amount of money each person will receive?

Write your answer here:

Sample responses:

Number of winners

Amount in dollar
each winner receives 
1 300
2 150
3 100
5 60
15 20

  • The amount in dollars received by each winner is 300 divided by the number of winners.
  • \( a=\frac{300}{n} \), or \( a\cdot n=300 \) (or equivalent), where \( a \) is the dollar amount a winner receives and \( n \) is the number of winners.
  • The amount in dollars, \( a \), varies inversely as \( n \).


3. A \( \frac{1}{2} \)-gallon jug of milk can fill 8 cups, while 32 fluid ounces of milk can fill 4 cups.

What is the relationship between the number of gallons and ounces? If you get stuck, try creating a table.

Write your answer here:

Sample responses:

If 4 cups contain 32 fluid ounces, then 8 cups must contain 64 fluid ounces. Because there are 16 cups in 1 gallon and 16 is twice as much as 8, there must be 128 fluid ounces in a gallon.

gallons  cups fluid ounces
\( \frac{1}{2} \)  8 64
1  16 128

  • Multiplying the number of gallons by 128 gives the number of fluid ounces.
  • \( f=8\cdot8\cdot2\cdot g \), or \( f=128g \) (or equivalent), where \( f \) is the number of fluid ounces and \( g \) is the number of gallons.
  • The number of fluid ounces, \( f \), varies directly as the number of gallons, \( g \).

page.title: 1.3.4: Writing an Equation to Represent a Relationship
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Clare volunteers at a local library during the summer. Her work includes putting labels on 750 books.

1. How many minutes will she need to finish labeling all books if she takes no breaks and labels:
  1. 10 books a minute?
  2. 15 books a minute?

Write your answer here:

Check your work:

a. 75 minutes
b. 50 minutes


2. Suppose Clare labels the books at a constant speed of \( s \) books per minute. Write an equation that represents the relationship between her labeling speed and the number of minutes it would take her to finish labeling.

Write your answer here:

Check your work:

\( s\cdot m=750 \), or \( m=\frac{750}{s} \), where \( m \) is the number of minutes and \( s \) is the speed in books per minute. The number of minutes, \( m \), varies inversely as speed, \( s \).

page.title: 1.3.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding Relationships between Quantities

There are times when the relationship between quantities may not be obvious. In some cases, the relationship between quantities might take a bit of work to figure out, by doing calculations several times or by looking for a pattern. 

Here are two examples.

1. A plane departed from New Orleans and is heading to San Diego. The table shows its distance from New Orleans, \( x \), and its distance from San Diego, \( y \), at some points along the way.

miles from New Orleans  miles from San Diego
100 1,500
300 1,300
500 1,100

1,020
900
 700
1,450   
\( x \)  \( y \)


What is the relationship between the two distances? Do you see any patterns in how each quantity is changing? Can you find out what the missing values are?

Notice that every time the distance from New Orleans increases by some number of miles, the distance from San Diego decreases by the same number of miles, and that the sum of the two values is always 1,600 miles.

The relationship can be expressed with any of these equations:

\( x+y=1,600 \) 
\( y=1,600-x \) 
\( x=1,600-y \)

2. A company decides to donate $50,000 to charity. It will select up to 20 charitable organizations, as nominated by its employees. Each selected organization will receive an equal donation amount.

What is the relationship between the number of selected organizations, \(n\), and the dollar amount each of them will receive, \( d \)?

  • If 5 organizations are selected, each one receives $10,000.
  • If 10 organizations are selected, each one receives $5,000.
  • If 20 organizations are selected, each one receives $2,500.

Do you notice a pattern here? 10,000 is \( \frac{50,000}{5} \), 5,000 is \( \frac{50,000}{10} \), and 2,500 is \( \frac{50,000}{20} \).

We can generalize that the amount each organization receives is 50,000 divided by the number of selected organizations, or \( d=\frac{50,000}{n} \).

Try It: Finding Relationships between Quantities

A local business is going to hand out $20,000 in scholarships to students at local high schools.

What is the relationship between the number of students, \( s \), and the dollar amount each student will receive, \( d \)?

  • If there are 2 students selected, each student will receive $10,000.
  • If there are 5 students selected, each student will receive $4,000.
  • If there are 10 students selected, each student will receive $2,000
  • If there are 20 students selected, each student will receive $1,000.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write a model for the relationship between the number of students receiving scholarships and the dollar amount they receive.

There is a pattern:

10,000 is \( \frac{20,000}{2} \)
4,000 is \( \frac{20,000}{5} \)
2,000 is \( \frac{20,000}{10} \)
1,000 is \( \frac{20,000}{20} \)

The amount each student receives is $20,000 divided by the number of students or, \( d=\frac{20000}{s} \). The dollar amount each student receives, \( d \), varies inversely as the number of students, \( s \).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won‚Äôt get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I‚Äôd like to retry the self check.
I‚Äôm ready for the next activity.
